title-group.article-title: Environmental and thermal benefits of linking Brayton, absorption chiller, and organic Rankine cycles with low-enthalpy geothermal source at an arid-zone area of Libya

abstract.p: A combined system which consists of Brayton, LiBr/H2O absorption chiller, and HFC 245fa organic Rankine cycles has been developed and linked to a high potential low-temperature geothermal source of energy. Situated in an arid-zone area at Waddan City Libya, the geothermal source could provide sufficient energy for the City and surrounding villages and satisfy their full electrical demand of 100 MW in an uninterrupted and stable way. The system could also supply district heating and hot water. The simulated results show that the output power and thermal efficiency of the combined cycles were improved by 5 per cent and 1.5 per cent, respectively, compared to a standalone gas turbine and it also reduced carbon emissions by 55.7 per cent (291 g/kWh instead of 649 g/kWh). Incorporating district heating to the electrical energy raised the energy utilization factor to 55.1 per cent.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: The growing demand for electrical power and serious restrictions on thermal pollution has increased the need for developing more efficient power generation systems. The exhaust gases of a gas turbine carry a significant amount of high grade thermal energy that is usually expelled to the atmosphere without taking any further part in the power generation process. As reported by many researchers, the capacity and efficiency of the gas turbines are highly influenced by the degree of ambient temperature. Any variation in the ambient temperature will affect the discharge temperature of the compressor, the inlet temperature into the turbine, the mass flow, the specific work, the specific consumption, and the output power. One of the most efficient ways to improve a gas turbine performance, especially those situated in remote hot climate conditions, is to combine it with an absorption refrigeration cycle to effect inlet air cooling. The waste heat of the gas turbine is used to operate an absorption refrigeration unit whose cooling effect reduces the air temperature at inlet to the compressor. This reduction in the temperature causes an increase of air density, an increase of mass flow through the turbine, and decrease the amount of work required to drive the compressor, and therefore, an increase of overall thermal efficiency of the plant with a constant output power, independent of ambient air conditions. For instance Cohen et al. [1] reported that the net power decreases by 5 per cent to 9 per cent of the ISO rated power for every 10 °C increase above the 15 °C ISO standard. Mohanty and Paloso [2] studied the feasibility of reducing intake air temperature of a gas turbine from 30 °C to 15 °C by adding a double-effect lithium bromide cycle energized by steam from a heat recovery steam generator. It was revealed that reducing the intake air temperature from ambient conditions to 15 °C would increase the gas turbine output power by 13 per cent. A modelling simulation using the ENBIPRO program was demonstrated by Kakaras et al. [3] on the integration of a technology to reduce intake air temperature in gas turbine plants. They simulated a 4.33 MW simple cycle gas turbine unit and a 144 MW combined cycle plant. A single-effect LiBr/H2O absorption chiller powered by waste heat from a heat recovery steam generator was used to cool the intake air of a gas turbine to 5 °C at ISO conditions. The authors concluded that for a simple gas turbine the air cooling system demonstrates a high gain in the output power and efficiency, whereas, in the combined cycle case, the absorption chiller can considerably increase the power output but with a reduction in the overall efficiency.

There is quite a number of research works on organic Rankine cycle (ORC) combined with other topping cycles such as solar, geothermal, traditional power plants, and biogas digestion for more efficient energy utilization. However, within the last 20 years, the number of low-temperature powered ORCs has increased due to the rapid development and understanding of the physical and thermodynamic properties of working organic fluids. This has encouraged large industrial enterprises to consider recovery of waste heat (especially low-temperature resources) with the option to convert the energy to useful electricity. For instance, Hettiarachchi et al. [4] simulated a 10 MWe ORC powered by low geothermal hot water temperature in the range 70–90 °C and cooled by water at a temperature of 30 °C. Four geothermal working fluids suitable for low-temperature applications were selected to be used in the simulation: ammonia, HCFC 123, n-Pentane, and PF5050. The authors presented cost-effective optimum design criterion for the ORC unit. The total heat exchanger area to net power output was used as the objective function. The results showed that the choice of working fluid can greatly affect the power plant cost. As revealed, ammonia was preferred over the other three fluids for its minimum objective function. However, the presence of wet vapour at the end of the expansion and high evaporation pressure limited its use in low-temperature geothermal applications. A performance analysis and optimization of 100 kW ORC unit driven by exhaust heat and using HFC 245fa as working fluid was presented by Wei et al. [5]. The cycle was simulated by developed software based on a platform called Modelica/Dymola. The cycle was powered by very high exhaust gas temperature at the range 337–377 °C (exceeded critical temperature of working fluid – 154 °C) and the condenser was directly cooled by air at a temperature range of 0–67 °C. The results showed that an increase in exhaust mass flow rate and inlet temperatures yields higher output net power and system efficiency but output net power and system efficiency deteriorate when air mass flow rate decreases with increased ambient temperature. It was also revealed that the highest net output power and system efficiency are achieved when the degree of sub-cooling was in the range 0.5–0.6 K. An actual binary fluid cycle plant, using HFC 134a as organic refrigerants was built and successfully operated in Chena hot springs, Alaska, for producing electricity [6]. The community in Chena was supplied with an electrical power of 400 kW. This power was achieved only when the binary cycle power plant was energized by low-potential hot water at 73.9 °C, 30.24 L/s and low-temperature cooling water in the range 4–7 °C. The low cooling water temperature in the condenser caused the thermal efficiency of the Chena ORC plant to increase to 8 per cent. This efficiency was impossible to achieve at a higher condenser cooling temperatures in the range 30 °C. More specifically, the greater the difference between source and sink temperatures, the higher the cycle thermal efficiency. Guo et al. [7] has screened 26 working fluids, among them were HFC 245fa and HFC 134. The screening was carried out based on the optimum condition of each fluid for low-temperature (80–100 °C) geothermal ORC power system. A detailed energy and exergy analysis was carried out using a computer program. Of 26 fluids investigated, HFC 245fa followed by HFC 134a were found the most suitable working fluids used in low-temperature geothermal applications when powered by heat source temperature at the range 80–100 °C.

sec.title: 2 OBJECTIVES
sec.p: The purpose of this study is to explore the performance of combined cycles consisting of a gas turbine, absorption refrigerator, and ORC when energized from low-temperature hot water artesian geothermal sources situated in an arid non-active volcanic zone close to the remote community of Waddan City, Libya. The wells are located near existing natural gas fields that require to be supplied with electrical power in order for the oil to be exploited. The absence of sufficient cooling water makes a gas turbine generator of choice. The aim of this simulation study is to obtain thermal and environmental benefits when the above-mentioned cycles are combined together. The effect of the variations of the ambient air temperature on other cycle parameters has been also investigated.

sec.title: 3 METHODOLOGY
sec.p:
The IPSEpro software package was used to simulate the proposed configuration [8]. The principle of mass conservation and the first law of thermodynamics are applied to each individual component of absorption refrigeration, ORC, and simple gas turbine cycles. Each component can be treated as a control volume with inlet and outlet streams, heat transfer, and/or work. The proposed low powered absorption and organic cycles were simulated as stand-alone cycles and then combined with conventional cycles such as simple gas turbine units for increasing overall thermal efficiency. The configuration utilized the natural gas and geothermal source (Fig. 1) combining a simple gas turbine to generate electrical power, a water-cooled half-effect chiller for inlet air cooling of the gas turbine and an ORC using HFC 245fa refrigerant. This was designed in order to provide Waddan community and surrounding villages with cooling air conditioning, refrigeration, hot water, and electricity. This would also contribute in minimizing global warming by reducing harmful gases that are emitted from electrical power stations. In addition, the existing natural gas fields at Waddan city could also encourage the general electricity company of Libya to independently supply the remote areas with electrical energy in order to minimize sporadic electricity blackouts from the National Grid. This would lead to great savings on the storage and transportation of the liquefied natural gas that fuels the current electrical generation network. In addition, the combination of the cycles would also motivate the local societies to share the world’s green energy production, by minimizing the emissions of harmful gases. It would also contribute in raising the living standard of the societies by providing new jobs and a high level of technical training for the local engineering undergraduates. Fig. 1
Existing artesian geothermal well

sec.title: 4 MODELLING DESCRIPTION
sec.p:
Figure 2 shows the proposed schematic diagram, with simulated basic results, of the water-cooled half-effect absorption chiller combined with a simple gas turbine, district hot water supply heat exchanger, and HFC 245fa ORC. Regardless of its higher initial cost, the half-effect chiller was selected over the single-effect one, in order to absorb more heat from the geothermal source and also to provide the highest cooling capacity that would be used to reduce the intake air temperature of the gas turbine compressor. The cycle’s configuration have been schematically built and simulated individually and assembled in such a way to provide an optimal utilization of the primary geothermal energy, and produce the desired mix of cooling, heating, and electricity. Fig. 2
Schematic with simulated output results of the combined cycles

These models are named as follows.
Stand-alone simple gas turbine unit which will be called, for simplicity, (configuration-1).
Simple gas turbine combined with water-cooled half-effect absorption chiller (configuration-2).
Simple gas turbine combined with the half-effect chiller, hot water supply heat exchanger, and HFC 245fa ORCs (configuration-3).

As can be seen from Fig. 2, one of the existing geothermal sources at Waddan city was used as a powering source of the half-effect chiller to produce a cooling effect of 4518 kW at a constant chilled water outlet temperature of 5 °C. This cooling capacity was used to cool the intake air of the gas turbine compressor in order to increase and stabilize the electrical output power at high and changing ambient temperatures. The gas turbine compression pressure ratio was selected to be 14/1. The turbine and the compressor isentropic efficiencies were 91 per cent and 87 per cent, respectively, [9]. The hot exhaust gas from the gas turbine was used to: first, heat the water within the heat exchanger (heat recovery steam generator) for district hot water supply, and second to energize the evaporator of the ORC. Inserting the hot water supply heat exchanger between the gas turbine and the ORC units would reduce the exhaust hot gas temperature to reach a reasonable powering temperature of approximately 200 °C. Using the exhaust hot gas at high temperatures (e.g. 544 °C) to energize the evaporator would definitely cause the ORC refrigerant to exceed its critical temperature of 154 °C; so, it was necessary, during the simulation process, to lower the hot exhaust gas temperature by installing a heat recovery steam generator upstream of the ORC. In the ORC, a high molecular mass (134.05 kg/k·mol) refrigerant (HFC 245fa) was selected. The ORC turbine isentropic efficiency was selected to be 80 per cent according to Pietra [10]. The cooling media for condensing the refrigerant was water at a mass flow rate of 376 kg/s and at an average temperature of 25 °C. The outlet cooling water temperature of the condenser was constant at 30 °C and the exhaust hot gas, after passing through the ORC evaporator, was rejected to the atmosphere at the lowest possible temperature of 85 °C (below this temperature an accumulation of solid carbon starts to formulate within the chimney). The cycles have been configured to provide approximately 100 MW of electrical power which roughly matches the electricity demand of the dwellings at Waddan city and surrounding villages. During the simulation process, the ambient temperature was varied between 22 °C and 40 °C at an average relative humidity of 44 per cent. This is to investigate the influence of the ambient temperature on other related parameters such as net produced electrical power, overall cycle thermal efficiency, CO2 emissions (footprint), and energy utilization factor (EUF).

sec.title: 5.1 Output power and thermal efficiency variations
sec.p:
Figure 3 shows the effect of the variations of the ambient temperature on the output power of the simulated cycles. It can be seen that when the ambient temperature is increased from 22 °C to 40 °C, the output power is decreased by 3.6 per cent in both configurations (1 and 2), whereas in the case of configuration-3, the output power was decreased only by 2.9 per cent; so, combining the ORC unit with the gas turbine and the absorption chiller will yield not only an increase in the total output power but also minimize the effect of high ambient temperatures on the performance of the gas turbine unit. It can be seen also from the same figure that despite an effect of the ambient temperatures, configuration-3 is still producing the highest overall output power. A small improvement in the output power and thermal efficiency was noticed when a half-effect absorption chiller is connected to the intake air heat exchanger of the gas turbine. For instance, the improvement in the power and the efficiency was as low as 0.3 per cent over the entire range of the ambient temperature (22–40 °C); however, great stability in the thermal efficiency and output power was achieved. The higher improvements were obtained when the ORC units were assembled with the other cycles. Fig. 3
Effects of ambient temperature variations on net electrical power produced

Figure 4 shows a remarkable improvement in the thermal efficiency of the combined cycles (configuration-3), despite its marked decline with increase in the ambient temperature. The improvement in the thermal efficiency in case of configuration-3 compared to the other configurations was 3.64 per cent at an ambient temperature of 22 °C and 4.39 per cent at 40 °C. It can be concluded also from this figure that the increase in the thermal efficiency, during an increase of the ambient temperature, was due to insensitivity of the ORC output power to the variations of the ambient air temperature. When comparing configuration-3 with the other two configurations (1 and 2), the increase of the ambient temperature has less impact on the thermal efficiency. Conversely, in configurations 1 and 2, the increase of the ambient temperature has a higher impact on the thermal efficiency (2.88 per cent versus 3.6 per cent). This indicates the thermal advantages of combining the ORC with the absorption chiller and the gas turbine and also indicates that a considerable economic gain would be achieved. Fig. 4
The effect of ambient temperature variations on the cycles thermal efficiency

sec.title: 5.2 Annual savings of the output power
sec.p:
With respect to the effect of the variations of the ambient temperature on the electrical power produced, Fig. 5 shows annual electrical power savings at different ambient temperatures. The total annual power savings from configuration-3 was 18 216 977 kWh. This amount was calculated in association with the weather data analysis of the region (multiplying the power produced by the number of repeating times each year of each temperature from 22 °C till 40 °C). Fig. 5
Ambient temperature effects on the total annual saved electrical energy

Figure 6 shows, in detail, the annual output power savings for each individual ambient air temperature. The highest saved energy (1 431 651 kWh) was obtained at an ambient temperature of 23 °C, because this daily temperature occurred most times per year. The lowest energy savings (352 380 kWh) was obtained at an ambient temperature of 39 °C, because this showed the lowest repeating value in the annual cycle. Fig. 6
Annual saving of electrical energy for each individual ambient temperature

sec.title: 5.3 Footprint/emissions of CO2
sec.p: Global warming is the increase of average world temperatures as a result of what is known as the greenhouse effect. Certain gases in the atmosphere act like glass in a greenhouse, allowing short-wave sunlight through to heat the earth’s surface but trapping the long-wave heat as it radiates back into space. As the greenhouse gases build up in the atmosphere, the Earth gets hotter. One of the main greenhouse gases is carbon dioxide (CO2) and the largest source of emissions globally is the combustion of fossil fuels such as coal, oil and gas in power plants, automobiles, industrial facilities, and other sources. The primary factors that alter CO2 emissions from electricity generation from year to year are the growth in demand for electricity, the type of fuels or energy sources used for generation, and the thermal efficiencies of the power plants.

Electricity generation accounts for approximately 40 per cent of global greenhouse gas emissions [11]. The natural gas fired power stations emit about 3142 kg of CO2 per one metric tonnage of natural gas [12]. This would produce carbon footprint of 500–600 g of CO2 per kWh which equals about half of that produced by the coal because gas has a lower carbon.

In the following text, an attempt was made to discuss and present the carbon footprints/emissions produced by all the models shown in Fig. 2. Figures 7 and 8 display the effect of the variation of the ambient temperature on the emission of the carbon. As can be seen from Fig. 7 that the highest quantity of the CO2 (≈649 g/kWh = 100 per cent) is emitted when the gas turbine run alone or linked with the absorption chiller (≈647 g/kWh = 99.7 per cent). The carbon footprint reduction was 3.7 per cent when three cycles assembled together without district heating energy. However, the highest reduction (55.7 per cent) was achieved to reach an average value of 291 g/kWh when the district heating energy was added to the total electrical energy produced. Fig. 7
CO2 mass emissions versus ambient temperature variation Fig. 8
CO2 percentage emissions versus variation of ambient temperatures

Figure 8 shows also a slight increase in the plot of CO2 emissions over the entire ambient air temperature range. The increase was around 3.63 per cent in case of configuration-1, 2.8 per cent in case of configuration-2, and as low as 1.4 per cent in case of adding the district heat energy to other combined cycles (configuration-3). It can be concluded that the highest carbon emissions were produced from the stand-alone gas turbine because of direct effect of the high ambient temperature on the intake air density. However, when the gas turbine was combined with other three cycles, the CO2 emissions sharply dropped below 50 per cent.

sec.title: 5.4 EUF variations
sec.p:
Evaluating the performance of the combined cycles including district heating water supply, by the thermal efficiency, is less useful. The better, but not ideal, parameter of the performance of the combined power cycles is the EUF [13]. It can be mathematically defined as follows
where WGT(net) is the net gas turbine output work, WORC(net) the net ORC output power, QHWS the district hot water supply energy, LCV the low calorific value, and m·Fuel the mass of natural gas.

Figure 9 depicts the EUF values for each individual configuration. The results presented by the bar chart below show equal EUF values for the configurations-1 and 2 as there were no significant improvements when the absorption chiller had linked with the gas turbine unit. A little improvement (3.6 per cent) has been accomplished by configuration-3 but without adding of the district hot water supply energy cycle. The greatest improvement (55.1 per cent) in the EUF values was obtained when part of the gas turbine exhaust energy used for supplying district hot water energy to the community at an average temperature of 70 °C which can be used in different domestic applications. Fig. 9
Average EUF for the combined cycles

sec.title: 6 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: The simulation results of the combined cycles have shown remarkable improvements in the output electrical power and overall thermal efficiency. They have also exhibited great reductions in the CO2 footprint emissions as well as good improvement in the overall EUF. The output power and thermal efficiency were improved by 5 per cent and 1.5 per cent, respectively, and the reduction in the carbon footprint/emissions was 55.7 per cent (291 g/kWh instead of 649 g/kWh), and by adding district heating to the electrical energy, the EUF was improved by 55.1 per cent.
